Sure. Here's a precise problem for a chemistry student to solve:

"A sample of radioactive material has a half-life of 2.5 days. If the initial activity of the sample was 200 counts per second, what would be the activity of the sample after 10 days?"
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

Final activity (A) = Initial activity (A₀) × (1/2)^(time elapsed (t) / half-life (t½))

In this case, the initial activity (A₀) is 200 counts per second, the half-life (t½) is 2.5 days, and the time elapsed (t) is 10 days. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

A = 200 × (1/2)^(10 / 2.5)

A = 200 × (1/2)^4

A = 200 × 1/16

A = 12.5 counts per second

So, the activity of the sample after 10 days would be 12.5 counts per second.
